awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Mechanisms of Lithiation and Delithiation Reactions in Layered Materials Combining Transmission Electron Microscopy and Atomic Scale Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This project focuses on understanding how batteries work at the atomic level. There are many methods for generating energy, but ultimately the limitation is often how to store that energy. Today, society is highly dependent on batteries, including rechargeable ones. Layered materials, such as molybdenum disulphide, may provide the key to improving these batteries. Transmission electron microscopy allows researchers to observe and identify individual atoms, but the data generated in such studies can only be fully interpreted using advanced materials-modeling methods. By working with engineers and chemists at the Yardney Division of EaglePicher, undergraduate and graduate students gain a broad practical understanding of batteries, while also developing the expertise and skills necessary to improve these batteries. In doing so, students need a combined understanding of ceramics, materials science, physics, chemistry and electrochemistry. A postdoctoral associate is performing in situ experiments and is linking the computer modeling to understand how the metals and layered material react.  Graduates are then well positioned to join companies across a spectrum (from transportation to medical implants) where they are urgently needed across the U.S. The broader impact of this research is ensured by participating in several community outreach activities including the UConn Mentor Connection (for high-school students) and the Kids are Scientists Too (KAST) K-12 summer program (which targets diverse and underrepresented groups and the Northeast Alliance). These laboratories also participate in a pre-college experience program for high-school junior and senior students where students interact with professors and graduate students.
 
TECHNICAL DETAILS: This project focuses on the characterization and modeling intercalation at the atomic scale. This research combines in situ experimentation in the transmission electron microscope with atomic scale modeling methods to improve our understanding of how lithium and sodium move into and out from layered materials (i.e. intercalation). These layered materials are a critical component of rechargeable batteries and the intercalation process is how recharging and charging is accomplished. This research compares the intercalation process for graphite and several transition metal dichalcogenides including molybdenum disulphide. This project makes full use of the recent advances in both characterization and the computing methodologies that allow the investigation of the mechanisms at the same length scales, and also builds a strong link to industry that relies on this technology and needs safer and more reliable batteries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Studying how lithium moves into, and out of, different layer materials like graphite and molybdenum disulphide at the atomic level is the key to improving our understanding of how lithium-ion batteries work. Expanding the study to other ions such as sodium, magnesium and even aluminum, may give clues as to how battery development can continue when lithium become too scarce, or too expensive, a commodity. (The price of lithium metal has already occasionally rivaled that of gold). Until recently, it was not possible to see the movement of lithium atoms in any material because it is so light an element—it’s atomic number is 3 with only hydrogen and helium atoms being lighter. Such atomic-level visualization is now becoming possible using the transmission electron microscope (because these instruments have improved dramatically in recent years), although most of the time we see the effect of the movement and not the movement itself.

Investigating the movement of lithium and these other atoms by modeling the processes in the computer gives a powerful new capability. We can simulate different possible mechanisms and compare how different atoms will move in these different materials. We can even create novel materials in the computer and then see how the mechanisms change for different moving atoms.

The process of moving into or out of layer materials is known as intercalation; it is very special because the structure of the host material does not change so the process is, or can be, completely reversible. Except when it isn’t, and that is often a surprise. We had indirect evidence for such structural changes, but the computer modeling confirms that these structural should indeed take place for certain layer materials, under certain circumstances. The process of intercalation has been known to occur for more than a hundred years, and extensive studied for over 50 years, but the details of how the process proceeds are still not definite, nor are the reasons for difference layer materials behaving differently.

This project has developed new approaches to study the mechanism and has linked microstructural characterization to atomistic computer modeling. The investigation of phase engineering to create new, optimized structures of these layer materials can only be carried out using computer modeling. The present program culminated in an exciting use of machine learning in the paper entitled “Data-driven search for promising intercalating ions and layered materials for metal-ion batteries” which has been accepted for publication in the Journal of Materials Science. The PI is so excited about this work that he encouraged Dr. Parida to submit her paper to the journal where he is the Editor-in-Chief! He had to blind himself to the whole process after appointing Prof. Jean-François Gohy of Lille University to handle the review. The co-PI, Prof. Dongare) is now making machine learning a core competency for his research group.

The other important outcomes of the program are that of the three postdocs who shared the one postdoctoral position, one gained the position of Assistant Professor at a major teaching school in India, one returned to a position in India and was promoted, and the third moved to a second postdoc position which led to her permanent position as a Scientist in a US National Laboratory. The student, who was fully funded by the project is now a software engineer at ComEd, an Exelon utilities company in the USA; she carried out the computer analysis for the project, gained her Ph.D. from the University of Connecticut and has published five published journal papers with another in preparation. Our program’s second co-PI (Dr. Dobley) was a battery expert from EaglePitcher (in Rhode Island) and this interaction is continuing although he has now been recruited away to Electric Boat (in Connecticut).

 


Last Modified: 12/10/2023
Modified by: C B Carter
